question: School Location
Teacher Sex
Grade
Subject
Other subject - specify
Is the teacher teaching or providing a learning activity for most students? (1st snapshot: 4 - 5 min)

options.label:
YES 
(This includes any activity that is related to class content, independent of its quality)
options.hint: Learning activities can include a teacher lecturing, small group/team work, or students working on a worksheet or reading independently. Note that if the teacher leaves the classroom, but has provided students with a learning activity, this would still count as a learning activity.

options.label:
NO 
(This includes any activity that is not related to class content, including those related to classroom management, disciplining, taking attendance, etc.)
options.hint: When the teacher is silently writing on the board without asking students to copy. Other examples of nonlearning activities include: when a teacher takes attendance, s/he may read the children’s names individually; when there are misbehaviors, s/he may stop the lesson to redirect student misbehavior; when there are outside disruptions, s/he may stop teaching to see what is going on; when checking homework, s/he may check each student’s homework individually, while the other students wait with nothing to do. In addition, basic classroom processes may be prolonged, such as transitioning to a new activity, getting materials ready for a lesson, or completing administrative tasks.

questions.tip: Please click on the response level hints (bulb icon) for some observable behaviour examples

question: Are students on task? (1st snapshot: 4-5 min)

options.label: L: 6 or more students are off task
H: All students are on task (one student may be off task)

questions.tip: Please click on the bulb for better clarity reg. students on task/ off task
questions.hint:
Students off task:
This includes students who are not participating in the learning activity provided by the teacher either because they are quiet but distracted, or because they are disrupting the class. For example, in the first category, students may be staring out the window, resting their head on the desk, looking down to the floor or at the observer, or sleeping. In the second category, they may be passing notes, whispering, talking to another student during an activity that does not require talking, moving around the class, shouting, or in any other way disrupting the class.

question: Is the teacher teaching or providing a learning activity for most students? (1st snapshot: 9 - 10 min)

options.label:
YES 
(This includes any activity that is related to class content, independent of its quality)

NO 
(This includes any activity that is not related to class content, including those related to classroom management, disciplining, taking attendance, etc.)

question: Are students on task? (1st snapshot: 9-10 min)

options.label: L: 6 or more students are off task
H: All students are on task (one student may be off task)

question: Is the teacher teaching or providing a learning activity for most students? (1st snapshot: 14 - 15 min)

options.label:
YES 
(This includes any activity that is related to class content, independent of its quality)

NO 
(This includes any activity that is not related to class content, including those related to classroom management, disciplining, taking attendance, etc.)

question: Are students on task? (1st snapshot: 14-15 min)

options.label: L: 6 or more students are off task
H: All students are on task (one student may be off task)

L1.label: Level 1
L1.description: In this classroom, the teacher does not ensure students time is spent on learning

L2.label: Level 2
L2.description: In this classroom, the teacher utlises time for learning by ensuring some students are on task

L3.label: Level 3
L3.description: In this classroom, teacher maximises time on learning by ensuring all students are on task.

L1.label: Level 1
L1.description: In this classroom, the teacher is ineffective at creating a supportive learning environment

L2.label: Level 2
L2.description: In this classroom, the teacher is somewhat effective at creating a supportive learning environment

L3.label: Level 3
L3.description: In this classroom, the teacher is effective at creating a supportive learning environment

L1.label: Level 1
L1.description: In this classroom, the teacher is ineffective at promoting positive behaviour

L2.label: Level 2
L2.description: In this classroom, the teacher is somewhat effective at promoting positive behaviour

L3.label: Level 3
L3.description: In this classroom, the teacher is effective at promoting positive behaviour

L1.label: Level 1
L1.description: In this classroom, the teacher is ineffective at facilitating the lesson to promote comprehension

L3.label: Level 3
L3.description: In this classroom, the teacher is effective at facilitating the lesson to promote comprehension

L1.label: Level 1
L1.description: In this classroom, the teacher does not check for any student's understanding

L2.label: Level 2
L2.description: In this classroom, the teacher is effective at checking only a few students' understanding

L3.label: Level 3
L3.description: In this classroom, the teacher is effective at checking for most students' understanding

L1.label: Level 1
L1.description: In this classroom, the teacher is ineffective at providing feedback to deepen students' understanding

L2.label: Level 2
L2.description: In this classroom, the teacher is  somewhat effective at providing feedback to deepen students' understanding

L3.label: Level 3
L3.description: In this classroom, the teacher is highly effective at providing feedback to deepen students' understanding

L1.label: Level 1
L1.description: In this classroom, the teacher is ineffective at developing critical thinking skills

L2.label: Level 2
L2.description: In this classroom, the teacher is somewhat effective at developing critical thinking skills

L3.label: Level 3
L3.description: In this classroom, the teacher is effective at developing critical thinking skills

L1.label: Level 1
L1.description: In this classroom, the teacher is ineffective at developing students' autonomy

L2.label: Level 2
L2.description: In this classroom, the teacher is somewhat effective at developing students' autonomy

L3.label: Level 3
L3.description: In this classroom, the teacher is effective at developing students' autonomy

L1.label: Level 1
L1.description: In this classroom, the teacher is ineffective at developing students' perseverance

L2.label: Level 2
L2.description: In this classroom, the teacher is somewhat effective at developing students' perseverance

L3.label: Level 3
L3.description: In this classroom, the teacher is effective at developing students' perseverance

L1.label: Level 1
L1.description: In this classroom, the teacher is ineffective at developing students' collaborative skills

L2.label: Level 2
L2.description: In this classroom, the teacher is somewhat effective at developing students' collaborative skills

L3.label: Level 3
L3.description: In this classroom, the teacher is effective at developing students' collaborative skills

observationInformation.name: TEACH Tool-support test
observationInformation.description: This is an assessment form to be used during classroom observation.

question: School Location
labels: Urban

question: Teacher Sex
labels: Male

question: Grade
labels: Grade 5

question: Subject
labels: EVS/Science

question: Other subject - specify
Is the teacher teaching or providing a learning activity for most students? (1st snapshot: 4 - 5 min)
labels:
NO 
(This includes any activity that is not related to class content, including those related to classroom management, disciplining, taking attendance, etc.)

question: Are students on task? (1st snapshot: 4-5 min)
Is the teacher teaching or providing a learning activity for most students? (1st snapshot: 9 - 10 min)
labels:
NO 
(This includes any activity that is not related to class content, including those related to classroom management, disciplining, taking attendance, etc.)

question: Are students on task? (1st snapshot: 9-10 min)
Is the teacher teaching or providing a learning activity for most students? (1st snapshot: 14 - 15 min)
labels:
NO 
(This includes any activity that is not related to class content, including those related to classroom management, disciplining, taking attendance, etc.)

question: Are students on task? (1st snapshot: 14-15 min)
Does the teacher treat all students respectfully?
labels: H: Treats all respectfully

question: Does the teacher use positive language with the students?
labels: H: Consistently uses positive language

question: Does the teacher respond to students' needs?
labels: H: Promptly responds to students' needs in a way that addresses the problem at hand.

question: Does the teacher exhibit any gender bias? Does s/he challenge gender stereotypes?
labels: H: Does not exhibit gender bias AND challenges gender stereotypes in the classroom

question:
From the above observations, how effective is the teacher in creating supporting learning environment in this classroom? 
(1 - completely ineffective, 5 - most effective)
Does the teacher set clear behavioural expectations for classroom activities
labels:
H: Sets clear behavioral expectations
OR
students are well-behaved throughout the lesson.

question: Does the teacher acknowledge positive student behaviour?
labels: H: Acknowledges students’ positive behavior that meets or exceeds expectations

question: Does the teacher redirect misbehaviour and focus on the expected behaviour, rather than the undesired behaviour?
labels:
H: When a problem arises, redirection of misbehavior effectively addresses the problem at hand and focuses on the expected behavior.
                           OR
the students are well-behaved throughout the lesson

question:
From the above observations, how effective is the teacher at promoting positive behavior in this classroom? 
(1 - completely ineffective, 5 - most effective)"
Does the teacher explicitly articulate the lesson objectives and relate classroom activities to the objectives?
labels: M: Either explicitly states a broad lesson objective OR the objective is not explicitly stated, but can be inferred from the lesson activities

question: Is the teacher's explanation of the content clear?
labels: M: Explanations of the content, when they occur, are somewhat clear

question: Does the teacher make connections in the lesson that relate to other content knowledge or students' daily lives
labels: M: May attempt to connect the lesson to other content knowledge or students’ daily lives, but the connections are superficial,confusing, or unclear

question: Does the teacher model by enacting or thinking aloud?
labels: M: Partially models the learning activity

question:
From the above observations, how effective is the teacher in facilitating the lesson to promote comprehension? 
(1 - completely ineffective, 5 - most effective)"
Does the teacher use questions, prompts, or other strategies to determine students' level of understanding?
labels: M: Uses questions, prompts, or other strategies that are effective at determining only a few students’ level of understanding.

question: Does the teacher monitor most students during independent/group work?
labels: M: Monitors some students

question: Does the teacher adjust teaching to the level of students?
labels: M: Slightly adjusts teaching, but this adjustment is brief and superficial

question: Does the teacher provide specific comments/ prompts that help clarify students' misunderstandings?
labels: M: Provides students with general or superficial comments/ prompts about their misunderstandings

question: Does the teacher provide specific comments/ prompts that help identify students' successes?
labels: M: Provides students with general or superficial comments/prompts about their successes.

question:
From the above observations, how effective is the teacher in providing feedback to deepen students' understanding? 
(1 - completely ineffective, 5 - most effective)
Does the teacher ask open-ended questions?
labels: M: Asks students at least 2 open-ended questions but does not build on student responses, OR the teacher asks 2 open-ended questions and 1 of them is a follow-up to a student response.

question: Does the teacher provide thinking tasks?
labels: M: Provides superficial thinking tasks.

question: Do students ask open-ended questions or perform thinking tasks?
labels: M: Students do not ask open-ended questions; however, they do perform superficial thinking tasks

question:
From the above observations, how effective is the teacher at developing critical thinking skills? 
(1 - completely ineffective, 5 - most effective)
Does the teacher provide students with choices?
labels: L: Does not explicitly provide students with choices

question: Does the teacher provide students with opportunities to take on classroom roles?
labels: L: Does not provide students with opportunities to take on roles in the classroom

question: Do students volunteer to participate in the classroom?
labels: L: Students do not volunteer to participate in the classroom

question:
From the above observations, how effective is the teacher at developing students' autonomy? 
(1 - completely ineffective, 5 - most effective)
Does the teacher acknowledge students' efforts?
labels: L: Does not acknowledge student efforts

question: Does the teacher have a positive attitude towards students' challenges?
labels: L: Negative attitude toward students’ challenges.

question: Does the teacher encourage goal setting?
labels: L: The teacher does not encourage students to set short- or longterm goals

question:
From the above observations, how effective is the teacher at developing students' perseverance? 
(1 - completely ineffective, 5 - most effective)
Does the teacher promote students' collaboration through peer interaction?
labels: L: Does not promote collaboration among students

question: Does the teacher promote students' interpersonal skills?
labels: L: Does not promote students’ interpersonal skills

question: Do students collaborate with one another through peer interaction?
labels: L: Students do not collaborate OR when students interact with oneanother, they display negative behaviors.

question:
From the above observations, how effective is the teacher at developing students' collaborative skills? 
(1 - completely ineffective, 5 - most effective)

solutionInfo.name: TEACH Tool-support test
